Graphical abstract For low temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx with ammonia, the highly effective Sm-Mn mixed oxide (Sm-Mn-O, the molar ratio Sm/Mn is 0.1) catalysts was developed. The effect of the calcination temperature on the structure, physicochemical and catalytic properties of the Sm-Mn-O catalysts was investigated in detail. The results showed that the Sm-Mn-O catalyst calcined at 450°C exhibited the highest activity, and after been calcined at >550°C its catalytic activity markedly decreased. With an increase in the calcination temperature, its surface area firstly increased and then decreased, and the poorly crystallized MnO2 in Sm-Mn-O was transformed to highly crystalized Mn2O3 phase. These changes influenced the adsorption ability of the Sm-Mn-O catalyst for NH3 or NO+O2. After calcination at >550°C, the contents of Mn4+ and adsorbed oxygen (OS) on the surface of Sm-Mn-O decreased obviously, resulting in the decrease in its catalytic properties for the NO oxidation and transformation of bridged nitrite to active intermediate of bidentate nitrate. Conversely, its catalytic activity for NH3 oxidation was enhanced after being calcined at high temperature. These adverse factors cause the decrease in the SCR activities of Sm-Mn-O calcined at >550°C. Keywords Sm-Mn mixed oxide Calcination temperature Selective catalytic reduction NOx elimination NH3 reductant 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO, NO2 and N2O) are one of the most serious pollutants causing acid rain, ozone depletion and the green-house effect [1,2]. The emission control of nitrogen oxides from various combustion processes has been a major environmental concern relating to the air quality, and more and more strict regulations and laws were laid down to limit the emission of NO x from the factories and vehicles. Many methods, such as direct decomposition of NO x , NO x storage and reduction (NSR) and selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with ammonia, have been employed to reduce the NO x emissions in the presence of excess oxygen. Among these techniques, the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) has been regarded as the most efficient technology for abatement of nitrogen oxide [3,4]. As is known to all, there are many other harmful substances besides NO x in the gas emitted from power stations. Consequently, the outgoing gas was needed to pass through some specific devices to remove particle materials and sulfur compounds firstly, and then reached De-NO x system, in which the temperature of the gas flow is usually lower than 200°C [5,6]. Therefore, there is a great interest in the development of novel SCR catalysts with high activity at low temperature to control the emission of NO x from the stationary sources. Although vanadia-based catalysts have been widely used in the commercial applications of eliminating SCR, several distinct drawbacks limited the further application of this catalyst, such as the low activity and selectivity at lower temperatures, narrow working temperature window [7] and the toxicity of vanadia. Another kind of available commercial catalyst used in NH3-SCR process is Fe or Cu doped zeolites [8–16]. However, these catalysts generally behave the high catalytic activity for NH3-SCR only at relative high temperature. Recently, transition metal oxide catalysts have been found to possess excellent performances for NH3-SCR reaction at low temperatures, especially the metal composite oxides containing Mn, such as Cr-MnO x [5], Mn-Ni/TiO2 [17], MnO x -FeO x [18] and MnO x -CeO2 [19,20]. We have found that the presence of Sm can improve the catalytic activity of the MnO x catalyst for the low-temperature SCR reaction, enhance its both water and sulfur dioxide resistances, restrain the crystallization of MnOx and increase its surface area and the relative content of both Mn4+ and surface oxygen, and can increase the absorption amount of NH3 and NO on the catalyst. [21]. But the effect of the calcination temperature on the physicochemical and catalytic properties of Sm-doped MnOx is unclear. Herein, we investigated the effect of the calcination temperature on the physicochemical and catalytic properties of Sm-doped MnOx SCR catalyst. After that, we further clarified the relationship between the calcination temperature (the solid phase reaction) – the physicochemical properties – the surface SCR reaction – the catalytic performance for Sm-doped MnOx catalyst and the promotional role of Sm in the SCR catalyst of Sm-Mn mixed oxide. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalyst The Sm-Mn mixed oxide catalysts were prepared by the co-precipitation method. MnSO4 and Sm(NO3)3·6H2O were used as the manganese and samarium sources, respectively. Na2CO3 solution was used as a precipitator. Typically, weighed MnSO4 and Sm(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in deionized water at room temperature. Then this mixed solution and 0.2M Na2CO3 solution were simultaneously dropped to a beaker under stirring to keep pH of the synthesis solution at 9. After this synthesis solution was stirred for 24h, the formed solids were collected by filtration, and washed by deionized water and ethyl alcohol until the pH value of filter liquor was about 7.0. Then the solid product was dried at 120°C overnight, and finally calcined in air at 350–650°C for 4h. The catalysts prepared were designated Sm-Mn-0.1-X, where 0.1 was the Sm/Mn molar ratio in the synthesis solution and X was the calcined temperature. Sm/Mn molar ratios in the Sm-Mn-0.1-x catalysts were 0.09 detected by inductively coupled-plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), which is very close to the theoretical value (0.1). When Sm(NO3)3·6H2O was not added in this synthesis solution, pure MnO x was prepared and designated MnO x -X, where X was the calcined temperature. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns were recorded on a Brook/D8 diffractometer with Cu Kα Radiation (λ=0.154056nm) and collected at 2θ=10–80° with a step size of 0.06°. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020M surface area and pore size analyzer at −196°C. Prior to the measurement, the sample was degassed at 180°C until a stable vacuum of ∼5mTorr was reached. The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The SEM images were collected on a Nava NanoSEM 450 instrument operated at the beam energy of 3kV. Elemental analysis of the sample was done by ICP-AES on a TJA IRIS ADVANTAG 1000 instrument. The XPS spectra were recorded on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with a monochromatized Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6eV) and a passing energy of 25eV. C1s (binding energy 284.6eV) of adventitious carbon was used as the reference. The Mn 2p peak and O 1s peak were deconvoluted by using XPSPEAK 4.1 with a Shirley background and a convolution of Gaussian and Lorentzian functions (80:20). H2-TPR was carried out on a PX200 apparatus (Tianjin Pengxiang Technology Co. Ltd.) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 50mg of the sample (40–60mesh) were heated from room temperature to 750°C at 10°C/min in the mixed gas of 5vol.% H2/N2 (45mL/min). The hydrogen consumption was measured quantitatively by TCD. NH3-TPD was carried out on the custom-made equipment with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Hiden HPR20). 300mg of sample (40–60mesh) was used and pretreated at 450°C (350°C for Sm-Mn-0.1-350) in a flow of Ar (300mL/min) for 1h. After cooled down to room temperature, the sample was saturated with a flow of 500ppm NH3/Ar (300mL/min) for 1h and was flushed by Ar (300mL/min) for 1h, and then TPD was run in Ar (300mL/min) from room temperature to 450°C at 10°C/min. The signal of desorbed NH3 species (m/z =15) was recorded. NO+O2-TPD was carried out on the custom-made equipment with a NO x analyzer (Thermo Fisher Model 42i-HL NO-NOx-chemiluminescence analyzer). 300mg of sample (40–60mesh) was pretreated in 5vol.% O2/Ar (300mL/min) at 450°C (350°C for Sm-Mn-0.1-350) for 1h and cooled down to room temperature. Then the sample was exposed to a flow of 500ppm NO+5 vol.% O2/Ar (300mL/min) for 1h to reach saturated adsorption of NO x on the sample, followed by Ar (300mL/min) purging for 1h. TPD was carried out in Ar (300mL/min) from room temperature to 450°C at 10°C/min. In the NO or NH3 oxidation, 300mg of catalyst (40–60mesh) was used. The reactant gas for the NO oxidation was composed of 500ppm NO+5% O2/balanced Ar, and for the NH3 oxidation the mixed gas of 500ppm NH3 +5% O2/Ar balanced was used. Their total flow rate was 300mL/min and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was about 48600h−1. The concentration of NO and NO2 in the tail gas was detected by a Thermo Fisher NO-NO x -chemiluminescence analyzer. The in situ DRIFT measurements were performed on a Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer with a MCT detector. In the DRIFT cell with ZnSe windows connected a gas flow system, the sample was pre-treated at 450°C (350°C for Sm-Mn-0.1-350) in 5vol.% O2/Ar for 1h, and then cooled to 20°C in Ar. The gas flow rate was kept at 50mL/min. The background spectra were recorded at the certain temperatures during the cooling process, and background was subtracted from sample spectra accordingly. 2.3 Catalytic activity testing The catalytic performances of the MnO x and Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts for NH3-SCR in excess oxygen were investigated in a fixed bed quartz reactor at atmospheric pressure. 300mg of the catalyst (40–60mesh) was used and the reactant gas was 500ppm NO+500ppm NH3 +5% O2/Ar balanced. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was about 48600h−1. The concentrations of NO and NO2 in the reaction gas were analyzed by a Thermo Fisher NO-NO x -chemiluminescence analyzer. To avoid modest errors caused by the oxidation of ammonia in the convert of NO/NO x analyzer, an ammonia trap containing phosphoric acid solution was installed before the chemiluminescence detector [22]. The concentrations of N2O and NH3 were monitored by Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer by using least square method to eliminate the influence of other components in the gas flow with the help of TQ analyst software. The catalyst bed was heated at 2°C/min, and after the reaction temperature was stably kept for 1h the concentration of NOx was measured. NO x conversion (X(NO x )) and the selectivity to N2 (S(N2)) were calculated as follows: X ( NO x ) = C ( NO x ) i n − C ( NO x ) o u t C ( NO x ) i n × 100 % S ( N 2 ) = C ( NO x ) in + C ( NH 3 ) in − C ( NO x ) out − C ( NH 3 ) out − 2 C ( N 2 O ) out C ( NO x ) in + C ( NH 3 ) in − C ( NO x ) out − C ( NH 3 ) out × 100 % C(NO x )in and C(NO x )out was denoted the concentrations of NO x in inlet and outlet, respectively. C(NH3)in and C(NH3)out was denoted the concentrations of NH3 in inlet and outlet. C(N2O)out was denoted the concentrations of N2O in outlet. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of the calcination temperature on the catalytic activity Fig. 1 shows the NH3-SCR activities of the MnO x and Sm-Mn-0.1-X catalysts calcined at different temperatures. As shown in Fig. 1A, the activity of the MnO x -450 catalyst was close to the MnO x -350 catalyst. After been calcined at >550°C, the activity of the MnO x catalyst markedly decreased, and the highest NO x conversion over the MnO x -550 (MnO x -650) catalyst was only 80% (29%). When Sm was added in MnO x , its catalytic activity was largely improved (Fig. 1B), for instance, using the Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalyst, more than 95% NO conversion was obtained at 60°C and nearly 100% NO conversion at 65–200°C was kept. Like the MnO x catalyst, the activity of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst also obviously decreased with increasing the calcination temperature. However, the activities of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts are much higher than that of the MnO x catalysts after being calcined at the same temperature. Furthermore, the N2 selectivity on the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts calcined at different temperatures is very close (Fig. S1), indicating that the calcination temperature of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts has little influence on the N2 selectivity over these catalysts. On the other hand, the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts exhibited an exceptional SCR activity at low temperature compared with the commercial V2O5/WO3-TiO2 catalyst under the similar conditions (Fig. S2). In addition, the presence of 2% H2O in the reactant gas affected hardly the SCR activity of the Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalyst (Figs. S3 and S4), and the crystal structure (Fig. S5) of Sm-Mn-0.1-450 can be kept after 15h of the SCR reaction with 2% water vapor. After the Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalyst was pretreated in air with 10% H2O at 450°C for 15h, its catalytic activity could be well kept (Fig. S6). These results indicate that this catalyst has the excellent water resistance and hydrothermal stability, and is expected to meet the demand of applied conditions. 3.2 Effect of the calcination temperature on the physicochemical properties Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the MnO x and Sm-Mn-0.1-X catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2A, there are the diffraction peaks of MnO2 with low intensity in the XRD patterns of MnO x -350 and MnO x -450 catalysts, meaning the poorly crystallized MnO2 for these two catalysts. When the MnO x catalyst was calcined at >550°C, the diffraction peaks of Mn2O3 appeared. As for the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts, only the diffraction peaks of MnO2 with less crystallization were observed and no diffraction peaks of Sm species can be found (Fig. 2B), which clearly indicated that the Sm species were well-dispersed in MnO x . However, the diffraction peaks of Mn5O8 and Mn2O3 appeared for the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 catalyst instead of these of amorphous MnO2, and only the diffraction peaks of Mn2O3 were present for the Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalyst. The comparison of XRD spectrum between Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and MnOx-550 shows that the presence of Sm can restrains obviously the formation of Mn2O3, that is to say, the presence of Sm in the Sm-MnOx catalyst can restrain the crystallization of MnO x . The BET surface areas of the MnOx and Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts are listed in Table 1 . The results show that the surface area of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst was increased firstly and then sharply decreased with an increase in the calcination temperature. For example, the BET surface areas of the MnO x -350, MnO x -450 and MnO x -550 catalysts are 88, 97 and 23m2/g, respectively. Although the surface areas of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts exhibited the same change trend with the calcination temperature as the MnO x catalysts, the presence of Sm can obviously increase the surface area of the MnO x catalyst. For instance, the surface area of Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalyst reaches 135m2/g, and only that of the MnO x -450 catalyst is 97m2/g. Furthermore, pore diameter distribution and average/most probable (MP) pore sizes of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts calcined at different temperatures are shown in Fig. S7 and Table 1, respectively. The most probable (MP) pore sizes are mainly 3–50nm, and increased with the increase in the calcination temperature. In brief, the calcination temperature of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst obviously affects its surface area and the pore size. Fig. 3 shows the SEM images of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts before and after calcination at different temperatures. The Sm-Mn-0.1 precursor without calcination was well dispersed spherical particles. After calcination, the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts exhibited the adhered spherical particles. For Sm-Mn-0.1-450, adhered degree of the particles increased obviously because of higher calcination temperature, and the particle size was slightly increased. Since the as-synthesized sample was mainly MnCO3, MnCO3 decomposed during calcination at <520°C (TG/DTG curves, Fig. S8). When the calcination temperature increased from 350 to 450°C, more CO2 was generated and more porous structure was formed in the particle, resulting in the inflation of its pore size and an increase in its surface area (Table. 1) and particle size. After the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst was calcined at >550°C, some of the sphere particles have been destroyed and the size of spherical particles was decreased, probably due to transformation of MnO2 to Mn2O3 and the collapse of the porous structure. Fig. 4 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts calcined at different temperatures. There are two reduction peaks for all the catalysts. The α reduction peaks at 292 and 278°C for the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts are ascribed to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn3O4, and the α reduction peaks at 314 and 330°C for the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts are ascribed to the reduction of Mn2O3/Mn5O8 to Mn3O4 [23]. The β reduction peaks at 425–465°C for all Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts are ascribed to the reduction of Mn3O4 into MnO [24–26]. The amount of H2 consumed in the reduction peaks was calculated and shown in Table 1. It is apparent that the amount of H2 consumed was ranked in the order of Sm-Mn-0.1-450 (0.768mmol/g)≈Sm-Mn-0.1-350 (0.758mmol/g)>Sm-Mn-0.1-550 (0.695mmol/g)>Sm-Mn-0.1-650 (0.626mmol/g). Based on the crystalline phases in the XRD spectra, the theoretic ratio of α/β related to H2 consumption should be 2 for the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts, and the α/β value should be 0.5 for the Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalyst. However, the α/β values calculated by the H2-TPR curves for the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts are<2. This phenomenon shows that Mn2O3 species may be already existed and well dispersed on these two catalysts, resulting in the disappearance of the diffraction peaks of Mn2O3 species in the XRD spectra of the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts. It is interesting that the α/β value of the Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalyst is quite near to the theoretic value of 0.5, because of its good crystallinity. And the α/β value of the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 catalyst is 0.88, due to the presence of Mn5O8 species. Fig. 5 shows Mn 2p and O 1s XPS spectra of the MnO x and Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts calcined at different temperatures. The surface atom concentrations of Sm, Mn and O are also summarized in Table 2 . It can be found that with the increase in the calcination temperature, the surface concentration ratio of O/Mn was decreased for the MnO x and Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts, because of the transformation from MnO2 to Mn2O. The Mn 2p XPS peaks can be deconvoluted to three peaks for the MnOx and Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts (Fig. 5A and B). The peaks at 640.1±0.1 and 641.5±0.3eV are ascribed to Mn3+ and Mn4+ respectively, and the peak at 643eV is the satellite peak of manganese [27,28]. The atomic ratios of Mn4+/Mn on the catalyst surface were calculated by the XPS spectra using XPSPEAK 4.1. As shown in Table 2, the atomic ratios of Mn4+/Mn on the surface of the MnOx and Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts obviously decreased with increasing calcination temperature, due to the transformation from MnO2 to Mn2O3, as shown in the XRD spectra. For example, the atomic ratio of Mn4+/Mn was decreased from 58% (MnO x -350) to 26.1% (MnO x -650). Compared with the MnO x catalysts, the atomic ratio of Mn4+/Mn on the surface of Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst was decreased more slowly with the calcination temperature, indicating that Sm addition can inhibit or retard the transformation of MnO2 to Mn2O3. In the O1s XPS spectra of the MnOx and Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts (Fig. 5C and D), two peaks can be distinguished. The peak at 531.0±0.2eV is ascribed to surface oxygen (OS) including surface adsorbed oxygen (such as O2 2−or O−) belonging to defect oxide and hydroxyl-like group, and the peak at 529.0±0.1eV is attributed to the lattice oxygen (OL) [29,30]. The atomic ratios of OS/(OS +OL) on the surface of these catalysts were calculated and shown in Table 2. It is interesting that the atomic ratios of OS/(OS +OL) for both MnOx and Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts decreased with increasing calcination temperature. However, the OS/(OL +OS) value of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst is higher than that of the MnO x catalyst after being calcined at the same temperature. In a few words, the XPS results show that with a decrease in the calcination temperature of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst, the atomic ratios of Mn4+/Mn and OS/(OL +OS) on its surface were increased, which can improve its oxidation ability and may be favorable for the catalytic oxidation of NO to NO2. 3.3 Temperature-programmed desorption after adsorbing (NO+O2) or NH3 After the sample was exposed to a flow of 500ppm NO+5vol.% O2/Ar (300mL/min) for 1h at room temperature to reach saturated adsorption of NO x and swept with Ar (300mL/min) for another 1h, the TPD was run in Ar (300mL/min) at 10°C/min and the NOx-desorption curves on the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts calcined at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 6 . There are two obvious NO x desorption peaks at <250°C and >250°C, and the former is attributed to physisorbed NO x and decomposition of nitrite species [6] and the latter is ascribed to the decomposition of bridged nitrate species and bidentate nitrate species with higher thermal stability [31,32]. It can be found that the amount of desorbed NO x on the Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalyst is slightly higher than that on the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 catalyst, but the desorption temperatures are similar for two catalysts. Comparing with the NOx desorption amounts on Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450, the NOx desorption amounts on the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts were sharply decreased, especially for the Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalyst, which should be related to the surface areas of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts (Table 1). Furthermore, the top temperatures of desorption peaks over the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts are different from that over the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts, due to the difference in the interaction between nitrate/nitrite species and the surface of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts composed with different MnO x phases. The NH3-TPD profiles of the MnOx-450 and Sm-Mn-0.1-X catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . All catalysts exhibited a broad desorption peak of NH3 (m/z =15), and the areas of desorption peak decreased with increasing the calcination temperature of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst. And the area of desorption peak over the Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalyst is larger than that over the MnO x -450 catalyst. As the NH3 adsorption amount is related to the surface area of catalyst, the desorption peak areas per the specific surface area (Area/SBET) were calculated for the catalysts. The Area/SBET values were ranked in the order of Sm-Mn-0.1-350 (1.02×10−10)>MnO x -450 (7.6×10−11)≈Sm-Mn-0.1-450 (7.36×10−11)>Sm-Mn-0.1-550 (4.91×10−11)>Sm-Mn-0.1-650 (3.45×10−11). It can be deduced that not only the special surface area but also the MnO x phase of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst (shown in XRD spectra) affected the adsorption ability of catalyst for NH3, in which MnO2 phase is in favour of the adsorption of NH3. 3.4 NO and NH3 oxidation Fig. 8 shows the catalytic activities of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts for the NO oxidation. The Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts exhibited the close activities for NO oxidation at <250°C, and the activities of the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts were markedly decreased comparing with mentioned-above two catalysts. At >250°C, there is no difference in the catalytic activity of all the catalysts for NO oxidation, because of the limitation of equilibrium conversion. As shown in the XPS results, compared with the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts, the atomic ratios of Mn4+/Mn and OS/(OL +OS) on the surface of the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts were largely decreased, which weakened the catalytic abilities of the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts for the oxidation of NO to NO2. On the other hand, the lower NO adsorption abilities of the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts (Fig. 6) may be another reason of the lower catalytic activities of Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts for the NO oxidation. It is well known that NH3 oxidation is one of the reasons for the lower NO conversion at higher temperatures. Hence the catalytic activity of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst for the NH3 oxidation was tested and shown in Fig. 9 . The results show that, NH3 cannot be oxidized to NO x species without catalyst. The oxidation of NH3 occurred at >225°C for the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts. With increasing calcination temperature, the activity of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst for NH3 oxidation obviously improved, and NH3 can be oxidized to NO x even at 115°C over the Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalyst. These results well explain the fact that the activity of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst for the NH3-SCR was reduced gradually at high temperature and when the calculation temperature of the catalysts was increased to 550 and 650°C its catalytic activity for the NH3-SCR was sharply decreased. 3.5 In situ DRIFT spectra for surface reaction Prior to the testing, the catalyst was pre-treated at 300°C in Ar (50mL/min) for 2h, and then cooled down to 50°C and exposed to the mixed gas of 500ppm NO+5 vol.% O2/Ar (50mL/min). The in situ DRIFT spectra on the catalyst were taken at different times and shown in Fig. 10 . As shown in Fig. 10, there are many IR absorption bands at 1635, 1557, 1540, 1507, 1281 and 1200cm−1 for the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 catalyst. The band at 1635cm−1 is assigned to bridging nitrate [33–37]; the bands at 1557, 1540, 1507 and 1281cm−1 are assigned to bidentate nitrates [34,37–42]; the band at 1200cm−1 is attributed to bridged nitrites [39,43,44]. It is interesting that the band at 1200cm−1 was increased firstly and then decreased with an increase in the exposure time, and disappeared after 40min of blowing the mixed gas of NO+O2. And the bands of bidentate nitrate were increased obviously after 20min of exposure in NO+O2. These results indicate that NO species may be adsorbed on the catalyst surface in the form of bridged nitrite at first, and then bridged nitrite slowly oxidized to bidentate nitrate with more stability, which can disclose many active sites for the adsorption of the NO x species on the surface of the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 catalyst, leading to the sharp increase in the band at 1281cm−1 corresponding to bidentete nitrate. The in situ DRIFT spectra of the Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts are almost the same as that of the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 catalyst, because its surface properties are similar to Sm-Mn-0.1-350. On the contrary, the in situ DRIFT spectra of the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts are quite different from that of former two catalysts. Although the bands at 1294cm−1 (or 1333cm−1) ascribed to bidentate nitrate and 1200cm−1 (or 1209cm−1) ascribed to bridged nitrites in the in situ DRIFT spectra of the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts exhibited the same change tendency as those over the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts, a new band at 1455cm−1 (or 1441cm−1) assigned to ionic nitrate appeared [45] and markedly increased with increasing calcination temperature of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst. The absorption bands of bridged nitrites over the Sm-Mn-0.1 sample calcined at higher temperature would disappear after a longer time of exposure in NO+O2, indicating that bridged nitrite is more difficultly changed to bidentate nitrate over the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalysts calcined at higher temperature, due to its decrease in the catalytic oxidation ability. Since nitrates are the reactive species for the SCR reaction (shown in Fig. 11 ), the higher catalytic activity of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst calcined at lower temperature for the transformation of bridged nitrite to bidentate nitrate would result in its better SCR activity than the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst calcined at higher temperature. After the experiments of Fig. 10 were finished, Ar gas (50ml/min) was used to blow the catalyst instead of the mixed gas of NO+O2 for 1h, and then Ar gas was replaced by 500ppm NH3/Ar, while in situ DRIFT spectra of the catalyst were taken at different times and shown in Fig. 11. As the signals of nitrate/nitrite species and adsorbed NH3 species generally were overlapped each other in certain degree, the spectra of NO+O2 pre-adsorbed samples were collected as background and then subtracted from the spectra taken in this experiment, obtaining Fig. 11. As for the Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalysts, it can be found that negative bands appeared at 1254/1261cm−1, which should be position of the absorption bands of nitrate species, indicating that the nitrate species have reacted with NH3. While the bands at 3300–3000cm−1 ascribed to NH stretching vibration of NH3 coordinated on Lewis acid sites arose after NH3 adsorption [29,46,47]. In the in situ DRIFT spectra of the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts, a strong band at 1377 or 1365cm−1 attributed to the intermediate adsorbed species from ammonia oxidization appeared and its intensity increased with the increase in the exposure time of NH3 [34,48], due to their higher catalytic activity for NH3 oxidation (Fig. 9). These intermediates may result in the formation of unexpected NO x rather than taking part in NH3-SCR reaction, leading to the decrease in the NH3-SCR activity of the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts at higher temperature. In a word, the NO species can adsorb on the surface of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst in the form of bridging nitrate, bidentate nitrates and bridged nitrite. The front two nitrates can react with NH3 and are the active intermediates for NH3-SCR reaction. Bridged nitrites can be slowly oxidized to bidentate nitrate, the catalytic oxidation ability of the Sm-Mn-0.1 would be reduced after being calcined at higher temperatures, resulting in the slow transformation of nitrite species to nitrates, which is one of the reasons for the lower NH3-SCR activity of the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts. Over the Sm-Mn-0.1-550(650) catalyst, the species of ionic nitrates can be observed. Since these species of ionic nitrates covered over the active sites are inert for NH3-SCR reaction, the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 and Sm-Mn-0.1-650 catalysts exhibited the lower catalytic activity for the NH3-SCR reaction due to the decrease in the active sites. The in situ DRIFT experiment was also conducted over the MnOx catalyst, its results was shown in Figs. S9 and S10, and the results were similar to that of Sm-Mn-0.1-350 and Sm-Mn-0.1-450. 4 Conclusion The Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst was prepared by co-precipitation method and calcined at different temperatures. The effect of the calcination temperature on the physicochemical and catalytic properties of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst was investigated in detail. With increasing calcination temperature from 350 to 450°C, the catalytic activity of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst increased slightly, more than 95% NO were converted on Sm-Mn-0.1-450 at 60°C and nearly 100% NO conversion were kept at 65–200°C. After calcination at >550°C, its catalytic activity was markedly decreased. With increasing the calcination temperature from 350 to 650°C, the surface area of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst firstly increased and then decreased, and the Sm-Mn-0.1-450 catalyst has the largest BET surface area; the MnO x phase in the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst was changed from the poorly crystallized MnO2 to highly crystallized Mn2O3. After calcination at >550°C, the relative contents of surface Mn4+ and adsorbed oxygen (OS) on the surface of Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst was decreased, resulting in the lower catalytic performance for NO oxidation and the transformation of bridged nitrite to bidentate nitrate over the surface. Furthermore, the presence of Mn2O3 crystal phase and the decrease of surface area of the Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst obviously weakened the adsorption of NH3 and NO species on the surface, resulting in the sharp decrease in the NH3-SCR activity of the Sm-Mn-0.1-550 (650) catalyst. The in situ DRIFT showed that the bridging and bidenate nitrates were active intermediates of NH3-SCR, and the ionic nitrates played a negative role in the activity of the catalyst because of the active site's coverage. coredata.dc:description: For low temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx with ammonia, the highly effective Sm-Mn mixed oxide (Sm-Mn-O, the molar ratio Sm/Mn is 0.1) catalysts was developed. The effect of the calcination temperature on the structure, physicochemical and catalytic properties of the Sm-Mn-O catalysts was investigated in detail. The results showed that the Sm-Mn-O catalyst calcined at 450°C exhibited the highest activity, and after been calcined at >550°C its catalytic activity markedly decreased. With an increase in the calcination temperature, its surface area firstly increased and then decreased, and the poorly crystallized MnO2 in Sm-Mn-O was transformed to highly crystalized Mn2O3 phase. These changes influenced the adsorption ability of the Sm-Mn-O catalyst for NH3 or NO+O2. After calcination at >550°C, the contents of Mn4+ and adsorbed oxygen (OS) on the surface of Sm-Mn-O decreased obviously, resulting in the decrease in its catalytic properties for the NO oxidation and transformation of bridged nitrite to active intermediate of bidentate nitrate. Conversely, its catalytic activity for NH3 oxidation was enhanced after being calcined at high temperature. These adverse factors cause the decrease in the SCR activities of Sm-Mn-O calcined at >550°C.
coredata.dc:title: A highly effective catalyst of Sm-Mn mixed oxide for the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with ammonia: Effect of the calcination temperature
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
